title: 108_s1451
content: The Act is titled the "Runaway, Homeless, and Missing Children Protection Act." It includes amendments to the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act, specifically in Section 302 regarding findings. The Congress finds that youth who are homeless or run away without parental permission are at risk of serious health and behavioral problems due to lack of resources, creating law enforcement issues in communities. These young people urgently need temporary shelter. The Federal Government is responsible for developing a national reporting system to address the urgent need for temporary shelter and services for homeless youth. This includes preventive and aftercare services, emergency shelter, extended residential shelter, and street outreach services. To address the needs of runaway and homeless youth, it is essential to provide opportunities for education, job skills training, and employment. Improved coordination between Federal programs serving this population is crucial for developing a long-term strategy. The heading for part A of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to "Basic Center". Grants for services provided under the Act are also addressed. SEC. 103 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to include testing for sexually transmitted diseases at the request of youth. SEC. 104 repeals an obsolete provision related to certain allotments. SEC. 104 repeals an obsolete provision related to certain allotments in the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. Section 312(b)(2)(A) of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to include exceptions for states with higher licensure requirements for child and youth serving facilities. Additionally, there is a provision for maternity group homes. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to include maternity group homes and parenting skills in eligibility criteria. A maternity group home is defined as a transitional living arrangement for pregnant or parenting youth. A maternity group home is a supportive living arrangement for pregnant or parenting youth to learn parenting skills and promote long-term economic independence. Limited extension of 540-day shelter eligibility period for youth under 18 years old in a program under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. Youth can remain in the program until their 18th birthday or 180 days after the end of the 540-day period. SEC. 109 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to involve McKinney-Vento school district liaisons in providing educational services to runaway and homeless youth. SEC. 110 addresses coordination agreements in Part B of the Act. Section 322(a) of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to include coordination of services with McKinney-Vento school district liaisons to ensure that runaway and homeless youth receive information about educational services. Youth under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act are provided information about educational services available to them. SEC. 111. PART B PLAN DEVELOPMENT amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to ensure proper referral of homeless youth to various services. SEC. 112 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to ensure coordination of programs and services for homeless youth, including consulting with the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. SEC. 113 clarifies grant authority. SEC. 113 clarifies grant authority under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. SEC. 114 makes a technical amendment regarding demonstration projects. SEC. 115 repeals an obsolete provision related to a study. SEC. 116 sets an age limit for homeless youth. SEC. 116 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to set an age limit for homeless youth seeking shelter in a center under part A to not more than 18 years of age. Section 388 of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to allocate $105,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and adjust funding for the following years. The Homeless Youth Act is amended to increase the funding allocation from 20-30% to 45-55% based on grant obligations and applicant quality. SEC. 118. REPORT ON PROMISING STRATEGIES TO END YOUTH HOMELESSNESS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the United States Interagency Council on Homelessness, must submit a report to Congress on strategies to end youth homelessness within 2 years of this Act. SEC. 119. STUDY OF HOUSING SERVICES AND STRATEGIES. SEC. 119. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will study housing services and strategies for youth exiting programs funded under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. The study will focus on long-term housing outcomes, available services, placement strategies, and models to prevent future homelessness. SEC. 120. RESTRICTION ON USE OF FUNDS. Amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to prohibit the use of funds for distributing sterile needles for illegal drug injection. Requires separate accounting for funds used for such programs. AMENDMENT TO MISSING CHILDREN'S ASSISTANCE ACT: Section 402 of the Act is amended to update the findings related to missing children. The Congress acknowledges the grave danger faced by abducted children, who are at risk of physical harm and sexual exploitation. Parents and law enforcement often lack resources for extensive search efforts due to children being moved to different locations. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children serves as a national resource center and works in partnership with various law enforcement agencies to find missing children and prevent child victimization. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children operates a network linking with missing children clearinghouses in 50 states, DC, Puerto Rico, Scotland Yard, Royal Canadian Mounted Police, INTERPOL, enabling instant transmission of images and information to law enforcement globally. SEC. 202. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Amends the Missing Children's Assistance Act to update the year for annual grants to the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children from 2005 to 2008. Passed the Senate on September 26, 2003. Reauthorize programs under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act and the Missing Children's Assistance Act.
